title: AI Analyzing and Explaining Scientific Figures
text:
As a part of my major (Biochemistry) class, we have to do a weekly discussion post summarizing a scientific article of our choice related. However, we all do research in different topics and it can be challenging to interpret figures and results, especially when I am not familiar with the techniques or molecules (proteins, genes, inhibitors, etc.) being used/mentioned.






Got it ‚Äî this is an EMSA (Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay) figure (Fig. 4B). Let‚Äôs break it down step by step:
üîé What‚Äôs in the figure?
Lane setup (grid above the gel):
Probe = DNA probe (labeled).
Nuc. Extract = nuclear extract (contains transcription factors).
IFN-Œ≥ = cytokine used to stimulate STAT1 signaling.
Ruxolitinib = JAK inhibitor (at 50 nM, 250 nM, 500 nM).
IgG = nonspecific antibody control.
Anti-pSTAT1 = supershift antibody to confirm STAT1 binding.
Gel bands (bottom image):
Shows DNA-protein complexes.
Red circles highlight the shifted bands (pSTAT1 bound to DNA probe).
When anti-pSTAT1 antibody is added, the complex is shifted even higher ‚Üí confirming specificity of STAT1-DNA binding.
Ruxolitinib treatment reduces the band intensity, showing inhibition of STAT1 activation.
üßæ Interpretation
Without IFN-Œ≥: no strong STAT1 binding.
With IFN-Œ≥: a clear shifted band (activated STAT1 binding DNA).
With increasing Ruxolitinib: reduced band intensity (dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1).
With Anti-pSTAT1 antibody: supershifted band ‚Üí proves that STAT1 is indeed binding to the probe.
IgG control: no shift, confirming specificity.
üìå In summary
This figure shows that IFN-Œ≥ activates STAT1 binding to DNA, and Ruxolitinib dose-dependently blocks this binding. The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody confirms that the DNA-binding protein is phosphorylated STAT1.



Perfect ‚Äî let‚Äôs do a detailed analysis of this Fig. 4B EMSA:

What the experiment tests

This is an Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA) using nuclear extracts from CCD841 cells.
The goal is to see whether STAT1 (activated by IFN-Œ≥) binds to a DNA probe and whether this is affected by the JAK inhibitor Ruxolitinib.
Antibodies (IgG or anti-pSTAT1) are included to test specificity of the protein‚ÄìDNA interaction.

Lane breakdown (based on the grid above the gel)

Probe only: no band shift ‚Üí probe runs at baseline.
Probe + Nuclear extract: weak/absent shift unless IFN-Œ≥ is present.

IFN-Œ≥: strong shifted band appears ‚Üí consistent with STAT1 activation.
Ruxolitinib (50, 250, 500 nM): progressive loss of the shifted band, showing dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1 DNA binding.
IgG: no change (control for nonspecific antibody).
Anti-pSTAT1: band supershifts upward ‚Üí confirms that phosphorylated STAT1 is the DNA-binding protein.


What the bands mean

The red circles highlight the DNA‚Äìprotein complexes (STAT1 bound to probe).
When Ruxolitinib concentration increases, the band intensity decreases ‚Üí JAK‚ÄìSTAT signaling is inhibited.
The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 is the definitive proof that the protein binding the probe is STAT1.

Overall interpretation

This figure demonstrates that:
IFN-Œ≥ activates STAT1 binding to DNA in CCD841 cells.
Ruxolitinib inhibits this activation in a dose-dependent manner.
The binding is specific to phosphorylated STAT1, confirmed by the supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody.



Something that immediately stands out is that without the prompt. Chat-GPT starts with a very general description of the figure, outlining each individual part and clarifying the experimental groups. Both versions give descriptions of the bands; however, the one with the prompt is much more detailed and it explains the logic more clearly. Both give fairly sound interpretations, but the answer given from the prompt contextualizes the results moreso than the answer without the prompt.
Chat-GPT is surprisingly able to extract a lot of data and reasoning within scientific figures. I personally find interpreting blot data, especially ones with so many experimental condiitons, quite challenging because most of the time, they are different forms of controls. But, Chat-GPT is a really good tool to help understand them.

title: AI Analyzing and Explaining Scientific Figures
text:

üîé What‚Äôs in the figure?

Both give fairly sound interpretations, but the answer given from the prompt contextualizes the results moreso than the answer without the prompt.

But, Chat-GPT is a really good tool to help understand them.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 2: Can it guess the personality type based on descriptions?
section: How will I prompt the LLM (Microsoft Copilot, GPT-5)?
text:
How will I prompt the LLM (Microsoft Copilot, GPT-5)?
In my last post, I had asked ChatGPT-5 to give me a description of ‚Äúmyself‚Äù based on my MBTI (16 personalities), which is ISTJ, the ‚ÄòLogistiann‚Äô.
I am now going to put portions of that into Microsoft Copilot GPT-5 and ask to see if it can guess the MBTI.
Microsoft Copilot Prompt: > Guess the MBTI with the description I give you. > Grounded and dependable, these individuals are driven by responsibility, reliability, and commitment. They value tradition, structure, and practicality, excelling in environments that require accuracy and consistency. Loyal and steady in relationships, they show care through actions rather than words. Their strengths lie in perseverance, organization, and a strong sense of duty, though they may sometimes struggle with rigidity or resistance to change.
Response: > This description strongly aligns with ISTJ ‚Äî the Logistician type. > Here‚Äôs why ISTJ fits so well:


Introverted (I): Shows care through actions rather than words, prefers reliability over emotional expression.
Sensing (S): Values tradition, structure, and practicality ‚Äî grounded in the present and focused on facts.
Thinking (T): Driven by responsibility and logic, not swayed by emotions.
Judging (J): Organized, committed, and thrives in structured environments with clear expectations.



ISTJs are known for their loyalty, precision, and sense of duty. They‚Äôre the backbone of many institutions ‚Äî dependable, methodical, and often the quiet achievers who keep everything running smoothly. Their challenge? Adapting to change and loosening up rigid routines.


It actually guessed it correctly! Now let‚Äôs try something else.
I asked ChatGPT-5 to create a ‚ÄòDay-in-the-life‚Äô story of someone who has this MBTI. This was the response: >Evelyn‚Äôs alarm rang at 6:15 sharp, just as it did every weekday. She liked the predictability of mornings ‚Äî coffee brewed while she folded yesterday‚Äôs laundry, a short walk around the block before sitting down at her desk. By 8:00, she was in the office, checking her to-do list against the team‚Äôs shared calendar. A colleague had forgotten to submit a report, so she quietly picked up the slack, knowing it was easier to handle it herself than risk the deadline being missed. Lunch was always the same ‚Äî a packed container of leftovers, eaten while she skimmed through local news. She preferred her routines; they gave her a sense of calm when everything else felt uncertain. In the evening, she stopped by her parents‚Äô house to drop off groceries. They hadn‚Äôt asked, but she noticed last week they were running low on basics, and it made her feel better knowing she could help. Later, back at home, she finished the day with a book she‚Äôd already read twice. The familiar story was like an anchor, grounding her before bed. It wasn‚Äôt a flashy life, but it was steady. And for Evelyn, there was comfort in knowing she could be counted on ‚Äî for herself, and for the people who mattered most.
I pasted it into Microsoft Copilot GPT-5 and ask it to guess the MBTI: > Evelyn is radiating ISTJ energy ‚Äî the Logistician type.

Here‚Äôs how her story maps to the ISTJ profile:



Introverted (I): She finds peace in solitude and routine, not in social stimulation. Her care is quiet and action-based ‚Äî dropping off groceries without being asked, handling tasks without fanfare.
Sensing (S): Evelyn is grounded in the present, attentive to details (like her parents‚Äô pantry), and prefers familiar, tangible experiences ‚Äî rereading a book, sticking to leftovers.
Thinking (T): She‚Äôs pragmatic and logical ‚Äî choosing to complete a colleague‚Äôs task to avoid missed deadlines, not out of emotional impulse.
Judging (J): Her life runs on structure: alarms, calendars, routines, and predictability. She thrives on order and responsibility.



ISTJs are the kind of people who keep the world running quietly in the background. They‚Äôre not flashy, but they‚Äôre rock-solid. Evelyn‚Äôs story is a love letter to consistency, duty, and quiet strength.



Once again, it‚Äôs correct!

title: Can LLM‚Äôs Plan My Science Experiment?
text:
Designing experiments in the lab takes a lot of effort and critical thinking. Additionally, you have to think of the feasibility and cost of such tasks. In my opinion, I find it difficult to be incredibly thorough why my experimental controls. For those that may not be as familiar with science experiments, controls are conditions that are kept constant. In essence, they act as benchmarks to compare the results of the experiment to. They help determine whether or not a change was significant or not. They help scientists determine if the changes in results are truly due to the factor being tested and not an external element.

What will I give Chat-GPT?
I currently just finished a proposal for my independent study. I am going to upload the ‚ÄòBackground‚Äô and ‚ÄòProject Goals‚Äô and see if an LLM can design a strong experiment.
Prompt: Design a feasible and cost-effective experiment.
*Disclaimer: I won‚Äôt upload my ‚ÄòBackground‚Äô to this blog post because it is quite a few pages, but here is the ‚ÄòProject Goals‚Äô
Specific Aims of Project:
-Investigate whether EBV promotes the development of the age-associated B cell (ABC) phenotype and inflammation in memory B cells via CD21 receptor internalization.
-Use gene editing, specifically CRISPR-Cas9, to knock out CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 in Mun-14 (an EBV+ B cell line that was adapted for increased neuroinvasion)16 and spontaneous lymphoblastoid cell lines (SLCLs) to interrogate their roles in EBV-mediated inflammation and neuroinvasion.
-Examine neuroinvasion in vivo using mouse models to track the distribution and localization of cells following receptor gene knockout
-Assess changes in inflammasome pathway gene expression following deletion of CD21, CXCR3, and/or CXCR4 in SLCLs derived from both active MS patients and healthy controls (also including unstimulated vs.¬†stimulated).
-Determine whether CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 function independently from each other or interact in common inflammatory and pro-migratory pathways.


LLM Response
üß™ Title: Investigating the Role of CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 in EBV-mediated Inflammation and Neuroinvasion in B Cells
üîç Overview and Rationale: Given the association between EBV-infected B cells and multiple sclerosis, and the surface markers (CD21, CXCR3, CXCR4) implicated in inflammatory signaling and neuroinvasion, this experiment will: Use in vitro and in vivo models to determine how knockout of these genes influences inflammatory behavior and neuroinvasive potential of EBV+ B cell lines.

üîß Methods / Techniques: 1. Gene Editing ‚Äì CRISPR-Cas9 Knockouts Cells: SLCLs from MS patients and controls + Mun-14 line Tool: Lentiviral CRISPR-Cas9 delivery system targeting CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 Verification: qPCR and flow cytometry for gene and protein knockout üîπ Controls: Non-targeting sgRNA control (negative) GAPDH or housekeeping gene control for RT-qPCR normalization Positive control: known cytokine or inflammasome activator (e.g., LPS + ATP) 2. Inflammatory Marker Expression (in vitro) Stimulate cells with EBV antigens or LPS Measure: NLRP3, IL-1Œ≤, IL-18, Caspase-1 (by qRT-PCR, ELISA, Western blot) Profile cytokine secretion (multiplex assay or ELISA: IFN-Œ≥, IL-6, TNF-Œ±) 3. Neuroinvasion Assay (in vivo & in vitro) üîπ In vivo: Mouse model: Immunodeficient (NSG) mice or humanized mice Inject knockout and control SLCLs (labeled with reporter gene, e.g., luciferase or GFP) Track migration/localization to CNS via bioluminescence imaging or IHC on brain sections üîπ In vitro: Use Transwell/Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB) assays: Human BBB model (co-culture of endothelial cells on upper insert and astrocytes/microglia below) Track migration of gene-edited SLCLs or Mun-14 cells across membrane 4. Cell Surface Marker Analysis / Immunophenotyping Flow cytometry for: ABC phenotype: CD11c+, T-bet+, CXCR3+, CD21low Inflammatory B cell profiles

üìä Data Analysis Plan:
qPCR/ELISA stats: ANOVA with post-hoc Tukey test
Flow cytometry: Compare mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) and percent positive
Neuroinvasion assays: Bioluminescence (IVIS) or fluorescence quantification, paired t-tests or two-way ANOVA
Gene interaction/synergy: Use combinatorial KO data to assess additive or synergistic effects on inflammation and migration
üìå Expected Results / Outcomes:
KO of CD21, CXCR3, or CXCR4 individually will reduce inflammatory cytokine production and possibly reduce migration in vitro/in vivo.
Combined KO likely yields greater reduction in MS-like inflammatory markers and neuroinvasion.
MS patient-derived SLCLs may respond differently than healthy-derived SLCLs ‚Äî possibly higher baseline inflammation and greater response to knockout.


My Thoughts
In terms of controls, Chat-GPT was able to identify most of what was needed. It was really interesting to see that the LLM recommend the same mouse breed that my lab actually does use in our research, mainly because there are tons of research mouse breeds used and it was able to guess the correct one. One thing that I wasn‚Äôt familiar with was the Transwell/Blood-Brain Barrier Assay. That was something we hadn‚Äôt even thought of because we have an established animal facility and can easily have access to animal studies. However, if we didn‚Äôt, this would be a good model to see the initial feasibility of neuroinvasion. Everything else seems very similar to the actual plan of my project!
Overall, given the correct background and initial questions, I think LLMs are capable to delivering a preliminary proposal. This is incredibly beneficial because it is difficult to create a complete and thorough experiment from the bottom up. This provides a solid foundation to build off of. I did want to add that there are some gaps in the process here, and something that the LLM doesn‚Äôt take into account is the capabilities and availabilities of the lab itself. Not every lab has access to flow cytometry, for example.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
What is MBTI?
MBTI stands for Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. It consists of a questionnaire to categorize people into 16 different ‚Äúpersonality types‚Äù.

There are four key areas of focus:

There are 16 combinations total and those correspond to the 16 personality types, which are grouped into four larger divisions.

Analysts
Architect, Logician, Commander, Debater


Diplomats
Advocate, Mediator, Protagonist, Campaigner


Sentinals
Logistician, Defender, Executive, Consul


Explorers
Virtuoso, Adventurer, Entrepreneur, Entertainer

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
section: What is my MBTI and how will I prompt the LLM?
text:
What is my MBTI and how will I prompt the LLM?
My MBTI is ISTJ, which means that I am a ‚ÄôLogistician‚Äù.

Chat-GPT 5 Prompt:

Write a detailed description and outline traits of someone with an ISTJ MBTI.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
Response
ISTJ Personality Overview

Type Code: Introverted ‚Ä¢ Sensing ‚Ä¢ Thinking ‚Ä¢ Judging


Nickname: The Inspector / The Duty Fulfiller


Core Drive: Responsibility, reliability, and upholding commitments.


Dominant Function: Introverted Sensing (Si) ‚Üí relies on memory, routines, and trusted methods.


Auxiliary Function: Extraverted Thinking (Te) ‚Üí focuses on efficiency, logic, and practical systems.


ISTJs are known for being grounded, dependable, and meticulous. They often feel a strong sense of duty to follow through on promises, meet obligations, and maintain stability. They like order, clarity, and practicality in their world.

Key Traits of ISTJs

Dependable & Responsible


Take obligations very seriously.


Known as people who can be counted on to deliver.


Detail-Oriented & Practical


Value concrete facts over abstract theories.


Notice small inconsistencies that others may miss.


Structured & Organized


Prefer planning ahead and sticking to schedules.


Thrive when rules, traditions, or systems are clearly defined.


Reserved but Steadfast


Introverted ‚Üí private with emotions, not quick to open up.


Quietly dedicated rather than showy.


Logical & Objective


Make decisions based on facts and efficiency.


Less swayed by emotions unless they relate to their values/duty.


Traditional & Loyal


Respectful of rules, hierarchy, and established practices.


Value stability in relationships and careers.

Strengths

Extremely reliable and trustworthy.


Excellent memory for details and past experiences.


Strong work ethic and perseverance.


Clear sense of duty and responsibility.


Loyal to people, institutions, and commitments.

Challenges

Can be rigid or resistant to change.


May come across as too serious or unexpressive.


Struggle with abstract or highly theoretical ideas.


Sometimes prioritize duty over personal needs.


Risk being overly critical (of self and others).

Work Style

Prefer clear expectations and step-by-step tasks.


Thrive in structured environments (law, finance, medicine, government, military, engineering, etc.).


Excel in roles requiring accuracy, consistency, and reliability.

Relationships

Show love through dependability and practical actions, not always words.


Value long-term stability over spontaneity.


Loyal, steady, and protective of their commitments.

‚ú® In short: An ISTJ is the type of person who keeps the world running smoothly ‚Äî grounded, diligent, and dependable, with a strong sense of tradition and order.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
Reflection
This part is more of a validation step for the next part as well as an investigation into how well LLMs understand the nuances of different persoality types beyond what is just directly stated. in terms of validity, I do see myself in a lot of these descriptions (it is my personality type after all). The ones that especially stood out to me were ‚ÄòChallenges‚Äô, ‚ÄòWork Style‚Äô, ‚ÄòRelationships‚Äô. I think these were extremely on the nose. I think one thing in particular doesn‚Äôt necessarily fit: ‚ÄúStruggle with Abstract or Theoretical Ideas‚Äù, but I think for me, this is a skill that came with time. Additionally, it has been a while since I‚Äôve gotten this result, so it is a possibility that I am no longer this ‚Äúpersonality‚Äù

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
Extra Prompt (for fun)
Prompt: > Do you think that there are only 16 personalities?
ChatGPT 5 Response: > Not really ‚Äî the idea of there being only 16 personalities comes from the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI), which categorizes people based on four binary traits (Introvert/Extrovert, Intuitive/Sensing, Thinking/Feeling, Judging/Perceiving).

That framework produces 16 combinations, but:



Human personality is far more complex.




Traits exist on spectrums, not binaries.
Two people of the ‚Äúsame type‚Äù can behave very differently depending on culture, upbringing, stress, etc.
Other models (like the Big Five) treat personality as continuous dimensions (e.g., Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism), which allows for many more nuanced combinations.
Neuroscience and psychology generally agree: personality is dynamic, not fixed ‚Äî it shifts with age, experience, and context.



üëâ So while the ‚Äú16 personalities‚Äù model can be a fun and sometimes useful shorthand, it‚Äôs definitely an oversimplification of human diversity.


Would you like me to compare MBTI vs Big Five to show how they approach personality differently?

My Thoughts: I think it‚Äôs interesting how ChatGPT 5 was able to answer a question seemingly looking for an opinion. Additionally, I am surprised that it gave the answer ‚ÄúNot really‚Äù, because I was expecting it to deflect and give an answer in between two opinions, rather than leaning to one side. I am not sure how LLMs are programmed to act based on opinion-based questions, but I am intriguied that it took somewhat of a stance. I wonder how far its opinions will go?

title: Can AI Solve Brain Teaser Word Puzzles?
text:
Back in 4th grade, my teacher would have us do brain teasers every day during lunch. She would write them down and project them onto the white board. There was no reward, no prize, just bragging rights. From this, I was inspired to see if LLM‚Äôs were any better than I was at 10 years old. Does Chat-GPT have the ability to guess a word or saying based on a very literal picture? Let‚Äôs find out!


Let‚Äôs see if I can figure out these eight teasers

Forget it (4 Get It)
Blackjack?
Somewhere over the rainbow
Back door?
Read between the lines
Blood is thicker than water
???
Cancelled check

The only one I missed was number 7, which was ‚ÄúBeeline‚Äù. Out of eight, I missed one of them, which honestly isn‚Äôt bad. Now let‚Äôs see how Chat-GPT holds up.


I pasted the exact photo into Chat-GPT, what does it say?
I added the prompt, ‚ÄúSolve these brain teasers‚Äù

Chat-GPT Response:
Sure! Below are the solutions to the brain teasers based on visual and wordplay clues:

‚ÄúGet it‚Äù repeated 4 times
Answer: ‚ÄúForget it‚Äù
(The word ‚ÄúGet it‚Äù is repeated four times, indicating the phrase ‚ÄúForget it‚Äù.)
‚ÄúJack‚Äù in a black box
Answer: ‚ÄúJack in the box‚Äù
(Literal interpretation of the phrase‚Äîa Jack in a box.)
‚ÄúSomewhere‚Äù above a rainbow
Answer: ‚ÄúSomewhere over the rainbow‚Äù
(Classic phrase and song lyric.)
The word ‚ÄúDOOR‚Äù is reversed
Answer: ‚ÄúBackdoor‚Äù
(The reversed word implies a door going back or behind.)
The word ‚ÄúREAD‚Äù between two lines
Answer: ‚ÄúRead between the lines‚Äù
(A classic idiom, shown visually.)
‚ÄúBlood‚Äù over ‚ÄúWater‚Äù
Answer: ‚ÄúBlood is thicker than water‚Äù
(Common expression indicating family bonds are stronger.)
The word ‚ÄúBeeeeeee‚Äù stretched out
Answer: ‚ÄúLong time no see‚Äù
(The extended ‚ÄúBe‚Äù indicates a long ‚ÄúB‚Äù, a pun suggesting ‚ÄúLong time no B(see)‚Äù.)
The word ‚ÄúCANCELLED‚Äù falling down diagonally like stairs
Answer: ‚ÄúCancelled check‚Äù
(The word is ‚Äúchecked down‚Äù or struck down stepwise‚Äîvisual pun.)
Let me know if you want explanations for any specific ones!




My analysis of the LLM performance
Chat-GPT was incorrect on two of the eight riddles, which means‚Ä¶I WIN!
All that aside however, the LLM actually perfomed better than I originally thought. It‚Äôs logic on most of the riddles was the exact same logic that I used. I originally believed it would be difficult for the LLM to decipher the words/saying behind the picture due to the necessary ‚Äòthinking outside the box‚Äô mindset behind brain teasers. Where it fell short was in the 2nd and 7th riddle. ‚ÄòJack in the Box‚Äô is also not completely wrong. I would‚Äôve likely guessed that after my original guess. For the 7th image, I think the LLM was a bit further off. It attempted to use a pun to justify the answer, but it didn‚Äôt make much sense.
LLM Grade: 75%, C


Reflection
The LLM‚Äôs ability to pick up on the subtleties present is quite fascinating. More specificaly, it was able to recognize puns in a visual form and translate it into a common saying. I was genuinely quite impressed to see that the LLM was able to pick up the majority of the solutions and go about solving them the same way I did. The only one that it was completely wrong for was also one that I couldn‚Äôt solve. Perhaps that is not necessarily a shortcoming on AI, but rather that the image itself was a more difficult riddle.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: About
text: Hi! My name is Alina and I am a student in COMM 4190 - Talking with AI: Computational and Communication Approaches! This blog is about my explorations using LLM‚Äôs :) I‚Äôm a senior studying Biochemistry and minoring in Data Science & Analytics!
